learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate knowledge of contemporary research about pedagogical approaches and student understandings in relation to mathematics. (APST 2.1)

Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of mathematical concepts, substance and structures (number, algebra, measurement, and geometry) and the supporting effective teaching strategies used to develop students depth of conceptual knowledge in mathematics. (APST 2.1; 3.3)

Demonstrate knowledge and use of curriculum, assessment and reporting knowledge to design learning sequences and lesson plans demonstrating a range of effective teaching strategies responsive to learning strengths and needs of all students from diverse linguistic, cultural, religious and socio-economic backgrounds. (APST 1.3, 2.3, 3.2).

Demonstrate knowledge and use of curriculum, assessment and reporting knowledge to design learning sequences and lesson plans demonstrating a range of effective teaching strategies responsive to learning strengths and needs of all students from diverse linguistic, cultural, religious and socio-economic backgrounds. (APST 1.3, 2.3, 3.2).

Identify and explain the use of a range of appropriate resources (mathematical language, symbols, hands-on manipulatives), including ICT as tools to design effective learning sequences to support and engage students mathematical learning. (APST 2.1, 2.3, 2.5, 2.6, 3.4)

Critically apply theories and current research about primary students development of mathematical concepts and proficiencies to create organised learning experiences, including challenging learning goals, for all students of varying ability in mathematics as required by Australian Curriculum: Mathematics. (APST 2.3, 3.1)

Apply personal mathematical content and pedagogical knowledge to critically reflect on the appropriate curriculum documents and the effectiveness of different approaches to teaching mathematics that cater for students across a full range of abilities, particularly the formative, summative and diagnostic uses of assessment data, and apply these approaches to support students diverse learning needs. (APST 1.3, 2.3, 2.5, 5.1)
Demonstrate the capacity to analyse and interpret student assessment data to evaluate student learning and modify teaching practice. (APST 5.4)

assessments.assessment_title: Portfolio of learning experiences - Part A
assessments.task_description:
Rationale: Teachers in primary school settings are increasingly required to show evidence of engagement in professional learning (AITSL, 2012). In many cases, portfolios can provide a way of proving that engagement in professional learning has taken place. This assessment task is an opportunity for you to produce a portfolio of mathematics teaching and learning experiences that highlight your professional learning as a pre-service teacher.

Task: This task is an individual assessment task which requires you to develop a portfolio of mathematics learning experiences, each focussed on specific mathematical content across the strands of the mathematics curriculum. It is an opportunity for you to demonstrate that you are developing the mathematical content knowledge (MCK) and pedagogical content knowledge (PCK) required to be a confident and capable teacher of mathematics in the primary classroom. 

For each portfolio entry you will focus on a different mathematical content area and year level within the parameters of the topic guide below, selecting a high-quality learning task/s with the potential to develop students' understanding of a key mathematical concept within that content area and year level.

Portfolio - Part A will include three portfolio entries aligning with the following topics:

  • Early number or place value (Years F-2)
  • Addition and/or subtraction (Years F-2)
  • Multiplication and/or division (Years 3-6)


Note: You will choose each year level once across Portfolio Part A and B, so that by the end of your portfolio you will have planned across all seven primary year levels.

Portfolio entry requirements

Each portfolio entry will include a detailed learning experience plan, a literature informed rationale and one of the following additional features (enabling & extending, response to diverse learning needs, ICT tools).

Each learning experience plan (400 words) will include:

  • an overview of the selected task/s (including sources)
  • focus prior, current and future curriculum content descriptions
  • focus mathematical language, skills and understandings
  • examples of specific problems posed and sequenced to support student learning
  • examples of specific resources used to support learning
  • teacher actions during the task/s, including formative assessment and content specific questions
  • anticipated student responses to the task/s, including expected misunderstandings, errors, and strategic approaches


Each rationale (350 words) will draw upon a breadth of contemporary mathematics education literature to demonstrate your understanding of the specific mathematical content (MCK) and the content specific teaching strategies (PCK) in your planning. You will explain how this knowledge informed your planning and justifying why the learning experience is likely to positively impact upon students' understanding of the target concept.

In Portfolio - Part A, each portfolio entry must include one of the following additional features so that each is covered at least once.

  • adjustments to the tasks to enable and extend students who require differentiation
  • specific teaching strategies responsive to the learning strengths and needs of a student/s from diverse linguistic, cultural, religious and socioeconomic backgrounds
  • ICT tools that could be used to support student understanding of the content
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments for this course will be submitted electronically via Blackboard and using Turnitin.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Using student data to design consecutive lessons
assessments.task_description:
Rationale: To best inform the teaching and learning of students, teachers need to use appropriate assessment tools/strategies to gain insights into the mathematical thinking of their students. In addition, effective teachers also need to seek to meet the learning needs of students by planning lessons that utilise assessment data. As such, teachers gather assessment data about student learning, interpret the data, respond to the data by planning purposeful learning experiences, and then reflect upon the effectiveness of the mathematics teaching and learning.

Task: This assessment task is an individual task that requires you to interview one primary school student (Foundation - Year 6) using a research-based interview protocol. You will administer the interview with the student, analyse and interpret the data, and write a report about the students’ understandings, drawing links between the knowledge they demonstrate and the mathematical strategies they use. In response to the data and the report, you will design a sequence of two mathematics lesson to address a particular learning need identified. Finally, you will provide a rationale for your planning decisions, making references to appropriate research literature.

Your task must include:

  • The data collected in the assessment interview including student responses and your own annotations (image of the assessment record sheet)
  • A report statement reflecting the student’s mathematical understandings (500 words)
  • A lesson sequence overview outlining the shared organisational information related to the two lessons (300 words)
  • Two consecutive mathematics lesson plans with the same mathematical focus, responding to assessment interview findings (600 words each)
  • A rationale for the lesson plans including justifications for the choice of mathematical focus and selected teaching strategies and resources, citing relevant academic literature (1000 words)
  • A reference list
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments for this course will be submitted electronically via Blackboard and using Turnitin.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Portfolio of learning experiences - Part B
assessments.task_description:
Rationale: Teachers in primary school settings are increasingly required to show evidence of engagement in professional learning (AITSL, 2012). In many cases, portfolios can provide a way of proving that engagement in professional learning has taken place. Portfolio - Part B will include four portfolio entries aligning with the following topics:

  • Early algebra (Years 3-6)

  • Measurement in upper primary (Years 3-6)
  • Geometry (Years 3-6)

Note: You will choose each year level once across Portfolio Part A and B, so that by the end of your portfolio you will have planned across all seven primary year levels.

learning_activities.topic:
Mathematical and pedagogical knowledge

The lecture this week will focus on understanding how you will develop confidence and competence as a teacher of mathematics in your mathematics courses.

In doing so, we will explore how your competence and confidence will improve by developing your understanding of 1. various teaching strategies (both general and content specific), 2. how children think about mathematics, 3. the mathematics curriculum and 4. mathematics concepts, skills, and strategies.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Mathematical and pedagogical knowledge The lecture this week will focus on understanding how you will develop confidence and competence as a teacher of mathematics in your mathematics courses. In doing so, we will explore how your competence and confidence will improve by developing your understanding of 1. various teaching strategies (both general and content specific), 2. how children think about mathematics, 3. the mathematics curriculum and 4. mathematics concepts, skills, and strategies.

learning_activities.topic:
Mathematical and pedagogical knowledge

In this tutorial you will critically reflect upon your current perception of mathematics education, and further explore modern mathematics pedagogy.

We will also explore your strengths and limitations related to specific content areas in mathematics to plot a pathway toward confidence and capability.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Mathematical and pedagogical knowledge In this tutorial you will critically reflect upon your current perception of mathematics education, and further explore modern mathematics pedagogy. We will also explore your strengths and limitations related to specific content areas in mathematics to plot a pathway toward confidence and capability.

learning_activities.topic:
Early number and Place Value

The lecture this week will focus on the concepts needed to teach early number to primary school students including the development of counting systems; subitising, place value knowledge; development of number sense. In addition to this, we will examine the Australian Mathematics Curriculum in relation to early number concepts. (APST: 2,1; 3.3)


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Early number and Place Value The lecture this week will focus on the concepts needed to teach early number to primary school students including the development of counting systems; subitising, place value knowledge; development of number sense. In addition to this, we will examine the Australian Mathematics Curriculum in relation to early number concepts. (APST: 2,1; 3.3)

learning_activities.topic:
Early number and Place Value

This tutorial will focus on the teaching and learning approaches for early number and place value. We will be examining the curriculum and designing learning activities. (APST 2.1, 2.3, 2.5, 2.6, 3.1; 3.3; 3.4)

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L05, L06, L07

learning_activities.topic:
Teaching addition and subtraction

In this lecture we are focusing on the models and strategies used to teach addition and subtraction. There will also be a focus on word problems, models for teaching, and the likely difficulties students encounter. (APST 2.1; 3.3)

Learning outcomes: L01, L02

There will also be a focus on word problems, models for teaching, and the likely difficulties students encounter. (APST 2.1; 3.3)

learning_activities.topic:
Supporting diverse learners needs

This lecture will focus on how you can cater for diverse learners in the mathematics classroom. In particular we will focus on effective teaching strategies responsive to learning strengths and needs of all students from diverse linguistic, cultural, religious and socio-economic backgrounds. (APST 1.3; 2.1; 2.3; 2.5, 2.6; 3.2, 3.4; 5.1)

Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L04, L05, L07

In particular we will focus on effective teaching strategies responsive to learning strengths and needs of all students from diverse linguistic, cultural, religious and socio-economic backgrounds. (APST 1.3; 2.1; 2.3; 2.5, 2.6; 3.2, 3.4; 5.1)

learning_activities.topic:
Assessment for learning in mathematics

In this lecture we will be focusing on Assessment in mathematics. In particular, different types of assessments in mathematics, assessment for learning; assessment of learning; the impact of assessment on students learning; the integral nature of planning and assessment; assessment scales; NAPLAN. (APST 1.3; 2.3; 2.5; 3.2; 5.1; 5.4)

Learning outcomes: L03, L04, L07, L08
learning_activities.topic_description: Assessment for learning in mathematics In this lecture we will be focusing on Assessment in mathematics. In particular, different types of assessments in mathematics, assessment for learning; assessment of learning; the impact of assessment on students learning; the integral nature of planning and assessment; assessment scales; NAPLAN. (APST 1.3; 2.3; 2.5; 3.2; 5.1; 5.4)

learning_activities.topic:
Assessment for learning in mathematics

This tutorial will focus on conducting student interviews as a form of assessment. In addition, you will analyse and interpret data to inform planning a mathematics lesson. (APST 1.3; 2.3; 2.5; 3.2; 5.1; 5.4)

Learning outcomes: L03, L04, L07, L08

learning_activities.topic:
Mental Computation

This lecture focuses on promoting number sense and mental computation; planning and implementing a structured program for mental computation development; the place of basic facts and instant fact recall; mental computation for rational number. (APST 2.1; 3.3)

Learning outcomes: L01, L02

learning_activities.topic:

This lecture will focus on the pedagogical approaches for mathematics. In addition to this we will focus on how to plan for learning in the mathematics classroom and numeracy across the curriculum. (APST 1.3; 2.1; 2.3; 2.5; 2.6; 3.1; 3.2; 3.4; 5.4)

learning_activities.topic:
Early algebraic thinking and reasoning

This lecture will focus on the fundamental concepts with regards to early algebraic thinking for primary school students (patterning, equivalence, and functional thinking). In addition, we will consider patterning to algebra and generalised arithmetic; the impact of the equals sign and other symbols on algebraic conceptual knowledge development. (APST 2.1; 3.3)

Learning outcomes: L01, L02

Geometry

In this lecture we will explore the big ideas in the geometry strand and develop shape awareness and knowledge. In particular, we focus on building a deep understanding of 2D and 3D shape and their relationships. (APST 2.1, 2.3, 2.5, 2.6, 3.3, 3.4)
